review: Every device needs to have a "unique" feature that warrants a purchase.Apple TV allows access to streaming iOS and mac devices and iTunes on iCloud and on local computers (great for not using data bandwidth if video stored on Harddrive, or if internet goes out, you can still watch movies)Roku 3 has arguably better line up replacing Twitch with HBO GO (but that is personal preference) and still gives access to amazon internet video. Also has a headphone output on the remote, if your afraid of disturbing others.Google Chromecast gives you access to Google Play content and streaming from pc, mac, iOS, and android devices (for $65 cheaper than Fire TV).Fire TV ... gives you DD+ (only beneficial if you have more than 5 channels of audio and used with an audio receiver that supports it), voice diction which is never as accurate or simple as text (apple tv can use iOS keyboard input) and many people would not even benefit (i have many deaf friends). It also gives you access to basic stripped down mobile games on your tv (if you don't already have a console to play, or an apple tv with an iOS device displaying on your tv, and maybe a bluetooth controller also.)The specs while on paper are impressive, need features that warrant the difference. I can't see this replacing any console which was its defining feature, and anything else that would require those specs.Apple TV has saved my hundred of dollars due to not requiring internet (can use Wi-Fi connection even without internet service to connect to my iTunes library). I can play full HD movies and not worry about going over my data caps.I am a person that lives by data caps, you don't realize how much data is used (3GB, 7GB or 9GB per hour for HD, Full HD, or UHD) until its limited. This is a huge problem with this device. It buffers videos even before you hit play, which will charge your account even if you don't want to watch the show. Also has anyone heard about the "mosaic" feature? Amazon released this product with a screensaver that would download the file over again every time it displayed, making users use more than 3 times their data cap. If you don't have data caps, then this is slowing down your speed as its adding competition on your network. (source https://gigaom.com/2014/06/30/amazon-fire-tv-bug-provides-another-reason-why-data-caps-are-anti-consumer/).

My sister, already having had the experience with this sort of thing, unpackaged the box when it arrived, went straight to the TV, plugged in the usb cord and the power cord and that was it. I can watch Amazon, Netflix, You Tube...a plethora of videos on my television now. Can't beat it, especially considering the price.
